options.A: patient with features suggestive of absence seizures and EEG showing 3Hz spike-wave discharges. Which of the following medications might worsen the seizure?

question_text: What EEG finding suggests a poor prognosis?

options.A: Prolonged suppression

options.A: IV diazepam

question_text: Patient with GTC seizure; what increases the recurrence of seizures?

options.A: Long duration

question_text: What is the normal response to hyperventilation on EEG?

options.A: Generalized delta wave

question_text: In the scenario of Panayiotopoulos Syndrome, which of the following is a characteristic feature of the syndrome?

options.A: Electrographic occipital spikes

EEG showed electrical discharges, and Brain MRI is normal. What is the next step?

An MRI of the head shows an old right frontal ischemic stroke. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for seizure treatment in this patient?

The last time she had a breakthrough seizure was at least 3 years ago. Her last EEG and brain MRI were normal. Which of the following is the appropriate management?

He has a history of 4 car accidents, one of which required ICU admission for 3 days. What is the best description for his seizure semiology?

question_text: What is the electrodecremental response in EEG associated with hypsarrhythmia?

options.A: 2/sec

question_text: Which of the following is associated with seizures and asymmetrical atrophy?

options.A: Glut1
Focal nonmotor with impaired awareness
Increased CBZ epoxide level

What is the most likely localization of these symptoms?

question_text: Valproic acid

options.A: Used primarily in Parkinson’s disease
options.D: A medication for migraine prophylaxis only

options.A: Sodium (Na)

options.A: Landau-Kleffner syndrome (LKS)

options.A: Spike and slow waves slower than 2 Hz

options.C: Increase the dose of current anti-seizure medications

options.A: Typical syncope

options.A: CTA
Irreversible visual loss
Phenytoin

options.A: Used primarily for Parkinson’s disease
options.B: An anti-epileptic drug used in seizure management

options.A: Lamotrigine

options.A: Absence of neck pain

options.A: Clinical diagnosis, no need for imaging

options.A: Coronary artery disease
